title: 108_s1967
content: The Act may be cited as the "Interest on Business Checking Act of 2003" and authorizes interest-bearing transaction accounts for all businesses. The "Interest on Business Checking Act of 2003" allows depository institutions to permit owners of certain accounts to make up to 24 transfers per month to another account. The "Interest on Business Checking Act of 2003" permits account owners to make up to 24 transfers per month to another account within the same institution. This account is considered a transaction account unless determined otherwise by the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System. The Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System determines the authority to offer demand deposit accounts to institutions prohibited by law. The Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System determines the authority to offer demand deposit accounts to institutions prohibited by law. The amendments made by paragraph (1) shall take effect two years after the enactment of this Act. SEC. 3. AUTHORIZATION OF INTEREST-BEARING TRANSACTION ACCOUNTS. Repeal of Prohibition on Payment of Interest on Demand Deposits in various acts including the Federal Reserve Act, Home Owners' Loan Act, and Federal Deposit Insurance Act. Joint rulemaking required. The Federal Deposit Insurance Act's Section 18(g) is repealed. Within two years of this Act's enactment, the Treasury Secretary and Federal banking agencies must issue joint regulations allowing interest and dividends on transaction accounts at regulated depository institutions. The regulations required by this subsection authorize the payment of interest and dividends on transaction accounts at depository institutions subject to regulation. They establish the scope of the authorization and types of accounts to which it applies, along with any limitations or restrictions consistent with the section's purposes. The regulations required by this subsection authorize interest and dividends on transaction accounts at depository institutions, with limitations and restrictions as needed. Effective date of regulations is within 2 years of enactment. Definitions for "depository institution" and "transaction account" are provided. The terms "depository institution" and "transaction account" are defined in the Federal Reserve Act. The term "Federal banking agency" is defined in the Federal Deposit Insurance Act. The amendments made by this section will become effective within 2 years of enactment or upon final regulations being issued. The amendments made by subsection (a) will be effective either 2 years after the enactment of the Act or when final regulations under subsection (b) become effective. Payment of interest on reserves at Federal Reserve Banks. The Federal Reserve Act is amended to allow depository institutions to earn interest on balances maintained at a Federal Reserve bank, to be paid quarterly at rates not exceeding short-term interest rates. The Board may create regulations regarding these payments and distributions. The Federal Reserve Act allows depository institutions to earn interest on balances at a Federal Reserve bank, paid quarterly at rates not exceeding short-term interest rates. The Board can create regulations for payment, distribution, and responsibilities of depository institutions. The responsibilities of depository institutions, Federal home loan banks, and the National Credit Union Administration Central Liquidity Facility regarding the crediting and distribution of earnings from balances maintained at a Federal Reserve bank. The responsibilities for crediting and distributing earnings from balances held at a Federal Reserve bank by depository institutions, including trust companies and corporations organized under specific sections. The Federal Reserve Act includes institutions like trust companies, corporations under section 25A, and branches of foreign banks. Amendments are made to allow pass-through reserves for member banks. Technical and conforming amendments are also made to the Federal Reserve Act. Section 19(c)(1)(B) of the Federal Reserve Act is amended by removing the phrase "which is not a member bank." Additionally, technical and conforming amendments are made to various sections of the Act. SEC. 5. INCREASED FEDERAL RESERVE BOARD FLEXIBILITY IN SETTING RESERVE REQUIREMENTS. Amends the Federal Reserve Act to allow for a reserve ratio not greater than 3 percent (which may be zero) and not less than 8 percent (which may be zero). SEC. 6. TREATMENT OF CERTAIN ESCROW ACCOUNTS. The text discusses the treatment of escrow accounts in real estate transactions, stating that certain activities related to these accounts will not be considered as the payment or receipt of interest under various laws. The text outlines specific activities related to escrow accounts that are excluded from being considered as the payment or receipt of interest under various laws, such as Public Law 93-100, the Federal Reserve Act, the Home Owners' Loan Act, and the Federal Deposit Insurance Act. These activities include absorbing expenses related to providing banking services for escrow accounts, forbearing from charging fees for such services, and any benefits accruing to the account holder. The text outlines activities related to escrow accounts excluded from being considered as interest payments under various laws. These activities include absorbing expenses for banking services, not charging fees, and providing benefits to the account holder.
